tasker.lib¶

The TaskLib class provides the methods for managing tasks.

class tasker.lib.TaskLib(config=None, manager=None)[source]¶
add_done(text)[source]¶

Adds a completed task. Uses the entry time as start and close :param text: Text of the completed task

build_task_dict(include_archive, only_archive)[source]¶

Builds a dictionary of tasks, much like get_tasks() but will read either file, or both.

get_counts(kind, include_archive, only_archive)[source]¶

Returns a dictionary of collections.Counter objects.

Parameters:
  • kind (str) – ‘project’ or ‘context’
  • include_archive (bool) – passed to build_task_dict()
  • only_archive (bool) – passet to build_task_dict()

The resulting dictionary looks like:

{'+SomeProject': Counter({'open': 2, 'closed': 1})}
get_extensions_to_hide()[source]¶

Compile a list of all extensions from the config file

get_tasks(path)[source]¶

Returns a dictionary of (line number (starting at 1), task text) pairs :rtype: dict :param path: path to the file to read :return: dictionary of line number, text pairs

graft(complete, priority, start, end, text)[source]¶

Return a single line of text representing the task. Does not append a line return :param boolean complete: True if task has been completed :param str priority: Single letter A-W for priority, or blank :param datetime.datetime start: Time the task was added to the list :param datetime.datetime end: Time the task was completed (or None) :param str text: remaining text of the task :return: string representation of the task

hide_extension(ext)[source]¶

Adds the extension to tasker’s list of hidden extensions. Hidden extensions will not appear in task lists.

list_tasks([by_pri, filters, filterop, showcomplete, showuid)[source]¶

Displays a list of tasks. :type by_pri: Boolean :param by_pri: If true, sorts by priority, if false, sorts by order in file :param filters: Words to filter the list :param filterop: all or any (the functions, not strings :param showcomplete: If true, shows completed tasks :param showext: If true, shows the normally hidden extensions of the task. :rtype: None

parse_task(text)[source]¶

Return a tuple of the following fields: complete - boolean priority - single letter (blank if complete or unprioritized) start - datetime.datetime object end - datetime.datetime object or None task - remaining text (including any projects or contexts) contexts - tuple of contexts (including ‘@’) projects - tuple of projects (including ‘+’) extensions - dictionary of extension values

Parameters:text (str) – text of a task.
prioritize_task(tasknum, priority, note=None)[source]¶

prioritize_task(tasknum, new_pri [,note]

Change the priority of a task. Will do nothing if task is closed. New priority can be A-Z but should be A-W.

Parameters:
  • tasknum (int) – Number of task to update
  • priority (str) – New priority character
  • note (str) – Optional note to append
reprioritize_text(text, priority)[source]¶

reprioritize(text, new_priority)

show_extension(ext)[source]¶

Removes the extension from tasker’s list of hidden extensions. Does not issue an error if the extension is not in the list

sort_tasks([by_pri, filters, filteropp, showcomplete])[source]¶

Returns a list of (line, task) tuples. Default behavior sorts by priority. Default behavior does no filtering.- Default filter operation is all (all must match). Default behavior does not list completed tasks Default behavior does not look in the done.txt file. To filter, provide a list of strings to filter by.

write_tasks(task_dict, local_path)[source]¶

Writes the working task_dictionary to the appropriate file :param dict task_dict: dictionary of (line: task) pairs :param filepath local_path: file path to write to

JUNK¶

The following methods are available to plugins through the cli property (for NewCommand objects) or the self.master property (for MinionCmd objects attached to SubCommand plugins).

TaskCmd.parse_task(text)¶

Returns a tuple of the following values:

  1. complete (boolean)
  2. priority (single character)
  3. start (datetime.datetime object)
  4. end (datetime.datetime object or None)
  5. task (string)
  6. contexts (tuple of contexts - words beginning with @)
  7. projects (tuple of projects - words beginning with +)
  8. extensions (dictionary of extension: value pairs)

parse_task() is a general utility function. The first five of these can be fused into a single line of text using graft().

TaskCmd.graft(c, p, s, e, t)¶

Returns a single text representing the task

The parameters match the first five components returned by parse_task().

TaskCmd.get_tasks(file_path)¶

Returns a dictionary of (line number, task text) pairs

Return type:dict
Parameters:path – path to the file to read
Returns:dictionary of line number, text pairs

Note

The first line is assigned the key 1 instead of 0

TaskCmd.write_tasks(task_dict, file_path)¶

Writes the working task_dictionary to the appropriate file

Parameters:task_dict (dict) – Dictionary of line-number: task pairs
Returns:results pair
TaskCmd.run_hooks(func_name, c, p, s, e, t, o, j, x)¶

Scans plugins for hooked features. Returns c, p, s, e, t.

This can allow for a plugin to write a listener method that adds something to the command queue or even alter the text of the todo.

Note

The task text is not re-parsed, so this could lead to confusion in the context and projects list and the extensions.

TaskCmd.add_task(text)¶

Appends a task directly to the file.

TaskCmd.add_done(text)¶

Adds a completed task to the list, allowing Tasker to serve as a log of actions.

This method calls TaskCmd.run_hooks() twice: once on creating the task and the second on completing the task.

TaskCmd.complete_task(tasknum, comment):

This is the method that do_do() calls.
